comment.authorname: R  i  c  h  a  r  d

comment.author: 23682063@N08
comment._content: They're beautiful, regal, tall and isolated. These days they're dwarfed by surrounding buildings. It's hard to believe how flat the surroundings were.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think this photo is about 1885. The clock was put to tender in 1884, and the Centennial Hall was only just begun (it opened in 1889). Ref: www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/history/foundations/Default.html Interesting to compare with a photo (Phillips) from almost exactly the same position about ten years later in c.1894 - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3575321672/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Henry King also photographed this view 10 years later (in landscape aspect) - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363490062/ The detail which shows up in his images when using the Persistent URL Zoom is breathtaking.

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: great photo. in 1875, the tower was tallest structure in sydney until 1879 when surpassed by the dome of garden palace.
